Directly across the street is a small convenience store for snacks, soft drinks, etc

Mar 25 2006	Great value and very pleasant	I stayed at the Harmony for just under a week and was very happy with it indeed. This was my first trip to Asia and I was apprehensive that the language barrier would prove problematic, but luckily the desk staff all spoke good English and were friendly (and patient!). The room was fantastic and much bigger than I'd expected for the cheap price, with a double bed, large TV, wardrobe, fridge, mirrors, several cabinets, tea table and two comfy chairs. There was also a spacious tiled bathroom with shower and complimentary toothbrushes, combs, soaps and shampoo. It seemed very quiet, and I didn't notice any noise from either outside or inside the building.There are no tea and coffee facilities as such, but each day a large flask of boiling water was left with tea cups and jasmine tea bags - this stayed hot well into the night, and it was nice to have a refreshing drink like this available. The room was clean, and maid service was good. The TV had 50 or so Chinese channels, plus the English-language Chinese channel, CNN, and HBO, which was fine. After all, you don't go to Beijing to sit in your room and watch TV!Taxi drivers do find it hard to locate Harmony, but don't let this put you off. The address is listed as 59 Suzhou Hutong, but the main entrance to the hotel actually faces Youtong Street which I think is what causes the problem (also like most Chinese hotels the English name is different from the Mandarin, which in this case is "Hua-mei-lun"). Get the hotel staff to write for you in Mandarin "please take me to Beijing station", which is literally a minute round the corner, and the taxi drivers will have no problem dropping you off there. There are also cards provided in the lobby, which say in English and Mandarin "please take me to ..." with a list of tourist sites in Beijing - these are very useful for showing to taxi drivers. Beijing taxis are wonderful, and ridiculously cheap. Short distances are all 10RMB (70p) and you can watch the meter go up in 7p increments when you travel further afield. I didn't find any taxi drivers who spoke English, but this doesn't matter if you can show them where you want to go on a card or a map. They're friendly and I always felt safe, which - as a single young woman - I can't say has always been the case in other countries! There are safety deposit boxes behind reception which I recommend you use, and are very safe as they're opened by one hotel key plus the key that they give to you. I was also delighted that they have adaptors for guests to use. When I asked for one at reception, I'd only just got up to my room when a cheery lady from housekeeping arrived with one, which was great. For the westerner there is cereal, eggs, fruit salad, coffee and perfectly decent croissants and jam. I recommend you also try some of the Chinese menu (just because you're abroad and you should!). The sweet biscuits and spring rolls are very nice, and there's also congee, which is a kind of bland but filling rice porridge. Right opposite the hotel there's a cavernous convenience store too, where you can buy water and other food for your room at very low prices.It's about a 20-25 minute walk to Wangfujing Street, Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City, which is perfectly fine. If you don't feel like walking catch one of the hundreds of cabs trundling past, or you can take the subway round the corner on Jianguomennei (cheap and safe, with signs in English and clear maps). It's actually very easy to navigate in Beijing, as you can follow the straight N-S E-W roads to get pretty much anywhere, and roads are marked in both Mandarin and English. Look at a map as you're walking along the grid or are in your taxi, and you'll soon get to grips with it. It's an extremely safe city, and I didn't once feel concerned about walking alone, even after dark. The street lighting is good, and there are plenty of neon signs to guide you around! If you do get lost (which it would be pretty hard to do) just hail an ever-present taxi and wave one of the hotel's cards at them - they'll get you back to somewhere you recognise.Obviously you'll want to see Tiananmen, the Forbidden City, the Great Wall and the Temple of Heaven whilst in Beijing. I also recommend visiting the Lama Temple, and taking a stroll through some backstreet hutong just to get a feel for the place. Wangfujing is a fantastic for buying souvenirs, and although it's overpriced in comparison to what you can get elsewhere it's still very cheap for Westerners. The added bonus is that by shopping on Wangfujing you'll get staff who speak English, and hopefully avoid the pressure and clamour of "hello lady!" that the street vendors greet you with. All the same it's fun to venture off into side streets to barter and see what's for sale.Food in Beijing is fantastic. If you don't speak Mandarin then your choice will be more limited, but look out for the places with picture menus (so you can point!) or English menus and you'll be fine. I was lucky enough to be with Chinese friends who helped explain menus to me, but there seem to be plenty of restaurants with English text too. Again, eating out is very cheap. If you're a little nervous at first, head to the Oriental Plaza (walk west along Jianguomen until it's crossed by Dongdan and you'll see the enormous glittering complex). There's some stunning food here, with stylish Chinese, Japanese and Thai restaurants (plus English menus). I had a couple of meals here and they were amazing, although more pricey than elsewhere... all the same, even the most expensive dinner was only 7 per head, which you'd easily pay for one dish in the UK! Lastly, it seems to take about 30-60 minutes to get to Harmony from the airport (and vice versa) depending on the traffic, and you should expect to pay around 100 or so RMB for the trip depending on the taxi. The hotel booked me a very nice car to take me there for 150 RMB - it was obviously a top-end taxi and as it was my last day I couldn't be bothered to haggle him down. On the way into Beijing a guy approached me offering to drive me in for 485RMB, which I managed to barter down to 120 (which I was particularly pleased with!). Again though it was an expensive private taxi, and I'm sure you could travel there for less in the ordinary red city taxis.I would definitely recommend this hotel, and Beijing, as a tourist destination. It was an incredibly positive experience coming here, so if you're heading for China enjoy your stay!
